comments.body: @pmlandwehr this is ultimately your decision as you will be maintaining the feedstock, but all that `jinja` might get in the way instead of helping. It will take some time for others to read the recipe and get what is going on. For example: if someone needs to copy-n-paste the URL to download the source and create a patch or check/change the checksum?

I was debating this, but I think that keeping to this format makes it relatively easier to stub out new recipes. Long-term, the best answer might be to make a small script to help with the stubbing instead - something less heavy than `skeleton` but that will fill out the sha256 values automatically.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +11,15 @@  fn: {{ name }}-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  url: https://pypi.io/packages/source/{{ name[0] }}/{{ name }}/{{ name }}-{{ version }}.tar.gz
  {{ hash_type }}: {{ hash_val }}

build:

comments.body: You should probably add the version limitation above too.
